p: Climate change is often linked to an increase in occurrence of draughts and/or floods. Data relating floods with diarrheal patients in Dhaka (Bangladesh) during 1988, 1998 and 2004 have been discussed [ 25]. They reported that Vibrio cholera was the first and Rotavirus was the second most frequent cause of diarrhea. Other causes of diarrhea were enterotoxigenic E. coli, Shigella, and Salmonella species. Water-related pathogens cause diseases, their surveillance, and possible interventions are discussed in Table 2 [ 26, 27, 28]. No comprehensive published work has been reported on the relationship between water quality and fecal coliforms with special reference to climate change in Pakistan.
